newsitem.title: LATVIA: LATVIA-SAULES BANK SEE MODEST 1997 GROWTH.
newsitem.headline: LATVIA-SAULES BANK SEE MODEST 1997 GROWTH.

text.p: Latvia's Saules Bank said on Friday that it expected to see modest growth in both assets and profits in 1997.
"Our draft budget for 1997 forsees growth of both assets and profit, but the rise will not be drastic," the bank's supervisory council chairman Yurii Shcetinin told Reuters in an interview.
He also said that Saules Bank in conjunction with Estonia's Tallinna Pank was considering setting up pan-Baltic financial service companies.
Shcetinin said the bank's budget that still has to be confirmed by the board on March 29 was rather conservative.
"This is a rather conservative budget," he said.
Saules earlier reported a fall in profits in 1996 to 866,000 lats from 1.48 million.
Saules strategy for 1997 includes strengthening the bank's position on the Latvian market by providing high technology card services.
"Through private clients, ready to use our Saules card, we would try to reach corporate clients," Shcetinin said.
"Handling salaries payments and providing cash withdrawal, account information and payment services to card holders is a way of doing that."
Saules provides its own card service, with the number of automated teller machines to grow to more than 40 from 19.
"This year Saules card holders will receive the added service of settling utility payments," Shcetinin said.
The Latvian banking sector now faces the competition of foreign banks as the first German and French banks have opened subsidiaries in Riga.
